questions.question: A 55-year-old male presented to the clinic for a routine check-up last week. He has no significant past medical history, but Automated Office Blood Pressure (AoBP) monitoring showed blood pressure readings of 142/94 mmHg, 138/86 mmHg, and 138/90 mmHg. Ambulatory blood pressure monitoring was advised; the average 24-hour blood pressure is 138/86 mmHg. According to the ACC/AHA hypertension classification, what category does his blood pressure fall into?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Stage 1 hypertension Explanation: Stage 1 hypertension is a systolic blood pressure between 130-139 mmHg or diastolic blood pressure between 80-89 mmHg. The patient’s ABPM shows systolic readings between 138-142 mmHg and diastolic values between 86-90 mmHg. Hypertension category based on the American College of Cardiology (ACC) Blood pressure category Systolic (mm Hg) Diastolic (mm Hg) Normal (Option A ruled out) < 120 < 80 Elevated (Option B ruled out) 120-129 <80 Stage 1 hypertension (Option C) 130 – 139 80 – 89 Stage 2 hypertension (Option D) ≥ 140 ≥ 90 Hypertensive crisis >180 >120 Hypertension Diagnosis Based on ABPM (ambulatory blood pressure monitoring) 24-h Average ≥ 130/80 mm Hg Awake (daytime) average ≥ 135/85 mm Hg Asleep (night-time) average ≥ 120/70 mm Hg Automated office Blood Pressure (AoBP) monitoring 3 readings to be taken Discard 1st reading The next 2 readings need to be averaged HTN if BP> 135/85 mmHg Reference: Blood pressure readings Harrison’s Principle of Internal Medicine, Edition 21st- Page 2076 Ambulatory Blood Pressure Measurement | Hypertension (ahajournals.org) Measurement of Blood Pressure in Humans: A Scientific Statement From the American Heart Association | Hypertension (ahajournals.org)

questions.question: A 60-year-old male with a BMI of 30 presents with frequent headaches and dizziness. His office blood pressure is recorded as 126/74 mmHg, but home readings range between 150/94 mmHg and 156/90 mmHg. Ambulatory blood pressure monitoring confirms these findings with higher readings outside the office. Which of the following is the most appropriate management plan for this patient?

options.C: Increase clinic visit frequency to monitor blood pressure
options.D: Diagnosis to be reconfirmed in 3 to 6 months

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Initiate antihypertensive therapy Explanation: The person in question most likely has masked hypertension. Lifestyle measures + antihypertensive drug therapy are recommended. ACC/AHA White coat hypertension Masked hypertension Definition Elevated clinic or office BP and normal out-of-office BP (on ABPM or HBPM) in individuals not receiving antihypertensive therapy Normal BP on clinic or office BP readings and elevated out-of-office BP readings in individuals not receiving antihypertensive therapy Diagnosis Cutoff for Office Blood Pressure: ≥ 130/80 mmHg Cutoff for Out-of-Office Blood Pressure (Daytime ABPM or HBPM): <130/80 mmHg Cutoff for Office Blood Pressure: 120–129/<80 mmHg Cutoff for Out-of-Office Blood Pressure (Daytime ABPM or HBPM): ≥ 130/80 mmHg Management Lifestyle measures Diagnosis to be reconfirmed in 3 to 6 months (Option D ruled out) Yearly follow-ups with ABPM to detect progression to sustained hypertension Antihypertensive treatment: Estimated 10-year atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease risk of ≥ 10% Hypertension-related target organ damage Lifestyle measures + antihypertensive drug therapy recommended (Option B) (Option A ruled out) Long-term out-of-office BP monitoring (Option C ruled out) Target Organ Damage Increased risk when compared to normotensive Significantly increased risk Cardiovascular risk is similar to that in patients with sustained hypertension Abbreviations: HBPM - Home BP monitoring ABPM - Ambulatory BP monitoring Reference: www.ahajournals.org/doi/full/10.1161/CIRCRESAHA.118.313219

questions.question: During a lecture on cardiovascular physiology, a professor explained that conditions causing unequal arm blood pressure often involve branches of the aortic arch. Which of the following conditions is not likely to cause a difference in blood pressure between the arms?

options.A: Aortic dissection involving the ascending aorta
options.B: Coarctation of the aorta distal to the left subclavian artery
options.C: Takayasu arteritis affecting the aortic arch

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Coarctation of the aorta distal to the left subclavian artery Explanation: Coarctation of the aorta that occurs distal to the left subclavian artery typically does not cause a difference in blood pressure between the arms because the left subclavian and right brachiocephalic artery originates from the aorta before the point of coarctation. As a result, blood flow to the arms remains relatively equal. Conditions causing unequal left and right arm blood pressures Pathophysiology Aortic Dissection (Option A) Dissection occurring at the site of arterial branching from the aorta Subclavian Artery Stenosis (Option D ruled out) Atherosclerosis or other causes of stenosis (Thoracic Outlet Syndrome) in the subclavian artery reduce blood flow to the affected arm Takayasu Arteritis (Option C) Chronic vasculitis that affects large arteries, particularly the aorta and its branches Coarctation of the Aorta Congenital narrowing of the aorta affecting branches of the aorta and narrowing proximal to left subclavian artery (Option C) Reference: Subclavian Artery Stenosis - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf (nih.gov) Harrison’s Principle of Internal Medicine, Edition 21st- Page 2106, 2112, 2080, 2105

questions.question: A 28-year-old male with a history of resistant hypertension and periodic muscle cramps is being investigated. Lab tests show hypokalemia, low plasma renin activity, and low aldosterone levels. Genetic testing reveals a mutation in the epithelial sodium channel (ENaC). What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Liddle syndrome Explanation: Liddle syndrome is characterized by a mutation in the ENaC, leading to increased sodium reabsorption, volume expansion, and hypertension. The presence of hypokalemia, low renin, and low aldosterone levels is consistent with this diagnosis. Mendelian causes of HTN Disease Mode of inheritance Pathophysiology Key Features Liddle syndrome (Option B) Autosomal dominant Hyperactive ENaC reabsorbs sodium at elevated levels, resulting in volume expansion and hypertension Hypokalemia Low renin Low aldosterone Gordan syndrome (Pseudohypoaldosteronism type II) (Option A ruled out) Autosomal dominant Mutations in regulatory proteins for the NCC (sodium chloride cotransporter) channel allow for unchecked activity, causing subsequent electrolyte and fluid overabsorption Hyperkalemia Normal glomerular filtration rate Polycystic kidneys Autosomal dominant Large cystic kidneys Renal failure Liver cysts Cerebral aneurysms Valvular heart disease Pheochromocytoma (Option D ruled out) Autosomal dominant Neoplasia of the adrenal medulla generates heightened levels of norepinephrine and epinephrine Associated with MEN-2A (Sipple syndrome) MEN-2B VHL syndrome NF-1 Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia (CAH) (Option C ruled out) Autosomal recessive Defects in steroid synthesis lead to buildup of intermediate metabolites with mineralocorticoid receptor activity 17- α hydroxylase deficiency: ↑ in aldosterone and thus HTN 11- β hydroxylase deficiency: ↑ in deoxycortisol which stimulates ENaC and causes HTN Glucocorticoid- remediable hyperaldosteronism Autosomal dominant Chimeric 11 β -hydroxylase/aldosterone gene Absent or mild hypokalemia Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6613461/ Harrison’s Principle of Internal Medicine, Edition 21st- Page 2080

questions.question: A 65-year-old man with a long-standing history of hypertension presents with occasional episodes of dizziness and transient visual disturbances. Neurological examination and fundoscopy are normal. A carotid ultrasound is performed to visualize the carotid arteries. Which of the following findings is not expected to be seen in this patient?

options.A: Atherosclerotic plaque formation in the carotid arteries
options.D: Turbulent blood flow in the carotid arteries

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Normal intima-media thickness Explanation: In patients with long-standing hypertension, there would likely be increased intima-media thickness due to vascular changes. Hence, normal intima-media thickness is the wrong option. Complications of HTN Heart disease Most common cause of death in hypertensive patients Left ventricular hypertrophy Brain disease The second most frequent cause of death Ischemic and hemorrhagic strokes Kidney disease Decrease in eGFR Chronic kidney disease (Option B) Arterial disease (Options A, C & D ruled out) Carotid arteries: Atherosclerotic plaque/stenosis (turbulent flow of blood) and intima-media thickness Aorta: Artery stiffening, aortic dissection Peripheral artery disease in lower extremity: Claudication symptom Eye disease Hypertensive retinopathy Reference: 2020 International Society of Hypertension Global Hypertension Practice Guidelines | Hypertension (ahajournals.org) Harrison’s Principle of Internal Medicine, Edition 21st- Page 2075, 76

questions.question: A 70-year-old Indian-origin male with a history of hypertension not on medications has chronic kidney disease (stage 2). His laboratory tests indicate an estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) of 60 mL/min and elevated protein in his urine. His present blood pressure is 142/90 mmHg. Considering his condition, which of the following antihypertensive medications is most appropriate to initiate?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Lisinopril Explanation: In patients with hypertension and chronic kidney disease, ACE inhibitors like Lisinopril and ARBs are preferred first-line agents for hypertension (unless contraindicated). They help control blood pressure and provide renal protection. ACC/AHA Guidelines for Hypertension Management Indications for Use of antihypertensives Secondary prevention of recurrent CVD events in patients with clinical CVD (defined as CHD, CHF, stroke) and BP ≥ 130/ ≥ 80 mmHg Primary prevention in patients with an estimated 10-year ASCVD risk ≥ 10% and BP ≥ 130/ ≥ 80 mmHg Primary prevention of CVD and low CVD risk in patients with BP ≥ 140/ ≥ 90 mmHg Blood Pressure Goal in Treating Hypertension BP target < 130/80 mmHg for adults with confirmed hypertension and known CVD or 10-year ASCVD event risk ≥ 10% Exceptions to Therapeutic Target of <130/80 mmHg Age >80 years Blood pressure <140/90 mmHg in previously untreated hypertensive patients who experience an ischemic stroke or TIA Acute therapy for most hypertensive urgencies and emergencies Abbreviations: ASCVD - atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease CHD - coronary heart disease CHF - congestive heart failure CVD - cardiovascular disease Patient type First Drug Add a Second Drug If Needed to Achieve the target BP If a Third Drug is Needed to Achieve the target BP Black patients (African ancestry): All ages CCB or thiazide diuretic ARB or ACE inhibitor Combination of CCB + ACE inhibitor or ARB + thiazide diuretic White and other non-black Patients: Younger than 60 years ARB or ACE inhibitor CCB or thiazide diuretic White and other non-black patients: 60 years and older CCB or thiazide diuretic ARB or ACE inhibitor Abbreviations: CCB - Calcium channel blocker ACE - Angiotensin converting enzyme ARB - Angiotensin receptor blocker Hypertension with other associated conditions Initial drug of choice Hypertension and diabetes ARB or ACE inhibitor Hypertension and chronic kidney disease (Option B) (Options A & C ruled out) ARB or ACE inhibitor Note: in black patients, good evidence for the renal protective effects of ACE inhibitors Hypertension and clinical coronary artery disease (Option D ruled out) β -Blocker plus ARB or ACE inhibitor Hypertension and stroke history ARB or ACE inhibitor Hypertension and heart failure Regardless of blood pressure, ARB or ACE inhibitor + β -blocker + diuretic + spironolactone. A dihydropyridine CCB can be added if needed for BP control. Pneumonic: ABDS Reference: Harrison’s Principle of Internal Medicine, Edition 21st- Page 2082 https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/jch.12237

questions.question: As a medicine resident, you are counselling a newly diagnosed hypertensive patient on lifestyle modifications to promote better health and help manage her blood pressure. Which of the following recommendations would be inappropriate or misleading for this patient?

options.A: Brisk walking for 15 mins/day, 5 days a week

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Brisk walking for 15 mins/day Explanation: The general guideline suggests at least 150 minutes of moderate aerobic activity per week, which translates to about 30 minutes a day, five days a week. Therefore, advising only 15 minutes per day might not adequately support effective blood pressure control. Hypertension lifestyle modifications Weight reduction BMI < 25kg/m2 (Option C ruled out) Dietary salt reduction <6g NaCl/day (Option B ruled out) DASH-type dietary plan (Option D ruled out) A diet rich in fruits, vegetables, and low-fat dairy products with reduced saturated and total fat content. Diet is also rich in potassium, calcium, and magnesium. Moderation of alcohol consumption ≤ 2 drinks/day in men and ≤ 1 drink/day in women Physical activity Regular aerobic activity, e.g., brisk walking for 30 min/day for 5 days a week. (Option A) Abbreviation: DASH, Dietary Approaches to Stop Hypertension Reference: Harrison’s Principle of Internal Medicine, Edition 21st- Page 2082

questions.question: A 55-year-old male presents with severe headache, nausea, and confusion. His blood pressure is recorded at 190/130 mmHg. Neurological examination reveals altered mental status, and the patient appears distressed. A fundoscopic exam shows retinal haemorrhages. What is the most appropriate classification of this patient’s condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Hypertensive emergency Explanation: This patient exhibits signs of end-organ damage (altered mental status and retinal haemorrhages), classifying his condition as a hypertensive emergency. Condition Features Treatment Approach Hypertensive Urgency Systolic BP > 180 mmHg and/or Diastolic BP > 120 mmHg without end-organ damage Stable patients, often noncompliant or discontinued therapy (Option A) Reinstitution or increase of oral antihypertensives No hospitalization required Gradual BP reduction over hours/days Hypertensive Emergency The same BP values as urgency but with end-organ damage Examples: Encephalopathy, stroke Retinal haemorrhages Aortic dissection MAHA Immediate 25% reduction in BP using IV agents (e.g., nitroprusside, nicardipine, labetalol) Malignant Hypertension Severe hypertension (BP > 180/120) with 3 or more target organ damage (Option C) It is a type of hypertensive emergency but with 3 or > 3 target organ damage Abrupt increase in BP in previously hypertensive or sudden onset in normotensive Values of BP are not important but it's the rapid rise and target organ damage which is important Pathology Diffuse necrotizing vasculitis, arterial thrombi, fibrin deposition in arterioles Fibrinoid necrosis in kidneys, brain, retina, etc. Intensive management often requires hospitalization and aggressive therapy Essential hypertension (Option D): Does not present with end-organ damage Reference: Harrison’s Principle of Internal Medicine, Edition 21st- Page 2086-2087

questions.question: A 65-year-old man with a history of type 2 diabetes and hypertension presents to his primary care physician for a follow-up appointment. His blood pressure is 160/95 mmHg. The physician wants to start an antihypertensive medication. What is the target blood pressure for this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) < 130/80 mmHg Explanation: For patients with diabetes, the target blood pressure is set at < 130/80 mmHg. This target is aimed at reducing the risk of complications associated with diabetes, including cardiovascular disease and kidney damage. Condition Target Blood Pressure Recommended Medications General Hypertension < 135-140/85-90 mmHg Initial: Thiazide diuretic, CCB, ACEI, or ARB (non-black) ; Thiazide or CCB (black) Hypertension with Diabetic Nephropathy < 130/80 mmHg (Option C) ACEI/ARB Malignant Hypertension Reduce MAP by 20-25% over 2 hours Nitroprusside, labetalol, fenoldepam End-Stage Renal Disease (ESRD) < 130/80 mmHg CCB (e.g., Amlodipine), Alpha blocker Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD) Grade I-III < 130/80 mmHg ACEI/ARB + Thiazide + CCB eGFR < 30 ml/min < 130/80 mmHg Diuretics (e.g., Metolazone) Reference: Harrison’s Principle of Internal Medicine, Edition 21st- Page 2086
